justification: “Bechara, Damasio, Damasio, and Anderson (1994) tested patients … largely using the Iowa gambling task… OFC patients were less sensitive to the punishment of losing money,” indicating the task was used to measure punishment sensitivity.

measured_by: probabilistic reversal gambling task with monetary loss
justification: “O'Doherty et al. (2001) reported an increased BOLD signal in the lateral OFC in response to monetary loss punishments in a gambling task,” showing the gambling (probabilistic reversal) task operationalised punishment sensitivity.

“Clarke, Horst, and Roberts (2015) trained marmosets to touch two visual stimuli … touching one stimulus would also produce a mildly aversive loud noise,” using the noise-punishment touchscreen procedure to assess how animals learned from punishment.

measured_by: delay-discounting lever-choice task (small immediate vs large delayed reward)
justification: “Mobini et al. (2002)… found that animals with OFC lesions were faster… in switching their preference to the smaller, immediate reward,” indicating the delay-discounting choice task was the measure of sensitivity to the punishing delay.
construct: sensitivity to delayed reward punishment / impulsive choice

justification: “Two studies in rats found that animals with lateral OFC lesions … were more sensitive to footshock punishments,” showing lever pressing followed by footshock served as the instrument to quantify footshock-based punishment sensitivity.

measured_by: lever-press task with probabilistic reward omission / time-out
justification: “Pais-Vieira, Lima, and Galhardo (2007) found that lateral OFC lesions increased rats' preference for a lever that earned a larger reward but was also more likely to result in the punishing omission of reward,” demonstrating that the reward-omission contingency was the measure of punishment sensitivity.
